comment.author: 53227388@N00
comment._content: Well this isn't much help, but was of interest to me. If you look at the background, you'll see that the statue to William Smith O'Brian isn't there; the statue in the background is Sir John Gray. The Smith O'Brian memorial was erected in 1870, but at the apex of D'Olier St and the quay. It wasn't moved to O'Connell St till 1929. The Gray memorial went up in 1879. Source: 78.137.164.74/~geograph/irishgeography/v34-1/sack.pdf Oh and here's a potted history of James Stott and his gas governor: www.gracesguide.co.uk/James_Stott_and_Co

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/woesinger] All is of help, and thanks for Sir John Gray. I have a recurring mental block about that statue always.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Another Ulysses moment: They passed under the hugecloaked Liberator's form. Martin Cunningham nudged Mr Power. —Of the tribe of Reuben, he said. A tall blackbearded figure, bent on a stick, stumping round the corner of Elvery's Elephant house, showed them a curved hand open on his spine. —In all his pristine beauty, Mr Power said. Mr Dedalus looked after the stumping figure and said mildly: —The devil break the hasp of your back! Mr Power, collapsing in laughter, shaded his face from the window as the carriage passed Gray's statue. From Episode 6: Hades

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
Trying to use the shop names on the left hand side to get a date. It's a long shot, but No. 47 might give a clue. McArthur is not listed in 1913 phone directory (of course he might never have been) but was living there in 1892 (marriage record), so would that give a latest date of 1913? Maybe..??! (Interestingly Wm Lawrence, photographer, was also listed in Upper Sackville St. Maybe we could ask him when he took it!

List of phone numbers:
From left to right in the 1913 phone book, they were: 
No. 49: Lemon & Co. Ltd., Wholesale Confectioner Ph: 1663
No. 49: Scott, Adam & Co., Wholesale Wine Merchants Ph: 718
No. 49: Bass, Ratcliff & Gretton Ltd., Brewers, Ph: 638
No. 48 : Little, Francis J, Solicitor, Ph: 908
No. 48: Royal Irish Yacht Club, Ph: 2299
47 - no mention but John Frederick MAcArthur lists this as his address in 1892
No. 46: Elvery, J. W. & Co., Ph: 411

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
And another Ulysses Link, re Lemon's Confectionary (there was a YMCA listed in phone directory too)
Pineapple rock, lemon platt, butter scotch. A sugarsticky girl shovelling scoopfuls of creams for a christian brother. Some school treat. Bad for their tummies. Lozenge and comfit manufacturer to His Majesty the King. God. Save. Our. Sitting on his throne, sucking red jujubes white. A sombre Y.M.C.A young man, watchful among the warm sweet fumes of Graham Lemon’s, placed a throwaway in a hand of Mr. Bloom
from here: www.architecturefoundation.ie/archive/2010/02/26/the-conf...

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: This is great. I love pictures showing Nelson's Pillar given its prominence in 'Ulysses'  (I'll forebear quoting Stephen's "Pisgah Sight of Paradise or The Parable of the Plums" and the story of the two ladies who climb it's stairs to see over Dublin as they are likely to be very familiar to many who view this site). What makes the picture even more fascinating is the removal of the two seated figures. Who were they? and Why? Probably we'll never know.

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content: Based on [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] date of pre 1896, I had a look at the Thom's Directory for 1895, 1894, and 1892 to help name the businesses on the street. Interestingly, MacArthur was there in 1894, but not in 1895, when No. 47 was taken over by Elverys. 1895 Listing No. 45: Bolger & Co, Wine and Spirit Merchant Robert J Cusack, Merchant Ed Stanley Lauder, photographer (which matches the tag entered) No. 46 and 47: Elvery JW and Co, Waterproof and gutta percha manufacturers John H Elvery (resident in Bray) William Elvery (resident in Carickmines) (No 47 in 1894 was MacArthur and Co, house and land agents, auctioneers and valuators, mortgage brokers; M. MacArthur, fellow Inst. Auctioneers, London) No. 48: James Stott and Co, Gas Engineers John Smallman sanitary and gas engineer and manufacturer's agent J Shanks and Co sanitary engineers Samuel Buckley and Co, patent die maker Stott and co Henry Pooley and Son James McConnell, illuminating and heraldic artist No. 49 Lemon and Co, Wholesale confection, lozenge and comfit manufacturers to the Queen Thomas Owens Lemon

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
So, good work, it's1894 at the latest, then.

Can Thom's do better than 1882 as the earliest possible date based on these businesses?

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
Following [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]'s suggestion, I had a look at the earlier Thom's. It looks like MacArthur's can help again. In 1884, they were not in this building. They were there by 1888, but next door (No. 48) was not listed. They weren't listed until the next available Thom's - 1891 - as J Stott, etc. 

I've compiled the info on the graphic below, but it would seem to me that photo dates 1889-1894...?
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04/7163920970/]

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] I'm speechless! Cannot thank you enough, and our very first example of someone being driven to construct a spreadsheet to make sense of what was going on...  :)

comment.author: 34574252@N02
comment._content: As an aid to dating shots of Sackville Street [O'Connell Street] with the O'Connell Monument - When the monument was unveiled on 15th Aug 1882 it was without its 'Winged Victories' and these were added during 1883. One of the biggest mistakes in a monument is virtually never mentioned – his coat buttons the ‘female’ side! www.flickr.com/photos/w77t/5378040894/in/set-721576229460...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Over on , [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] points out the supertall electric lights installed in 1892. I really think they would be visible here if this is after that date. There is a decent shot halfway down the page here showing one of the tall posts with a globe on top behind the monument. That would narrow this one down to 1889 to 1892, very close to our best guess at Bonafide Travelllers.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Yes, after 1892 there was an electric lamp in front of this statue, as well as both sides of the street. See www.flickr.com/photos/hwmobs/6811329243/sizes/o/in/photos... . So this must be before 1892.
